reason: The claim states 'the flux class of any compactly supported Lagrangian isotopy vanishes identically (Banyaga).' This conflates two distinct flux concepts. (1) Banyaga's flux homomorphism is defined on the group of (compactly supported) symplectomorphisms: Flux: Symp_0^c(M) -> H^1(M;R). When H^1(M;R)=0, every compactly supported symplectomorphism isotopic to the identity is Hamiltonian. (2) The flux of a Lagrangian isotopy L_t is a class in H^1(L_t;R), NOT in H^1(M;R). The vanishing of H^1(R^4;R) does NOT directly imply the vanishing of the Lagrangian isotopy flux in H^1(L_t;R) when H^1(L_t;R) is nontrivial (e.g., when L_t is a torus). The correct argument is: since nodes 1.3-1.5 construct K_t via ambient compactly supported Hamiltonian diffeomorphisms of R^4, the isotopy is Hamiltonian by construction. The standalone flux argument for abstract Lagrangian isotopies needs the additional observation that the ambient extension of the velocity field is closed on R^4 (not just on L_t), which follows automatically when the isotopy is already known to be ambient.
